task.title: Install Eucalyptus Release Packages
task.shortdesc: To install Eucalyptus from release packages, perform the tasks listed in this topic.

context.b: To install Eucalyptus from release packages

step.cmd: Configure the Eucalyptus package repository on each host machine that will run a Eucalyptus service:

info.p: Enter y when prompted to install this package.

step.cmd: (Optional) If you are a Eucalyptus subscriber, you will receive two RPM package files containing your license for subscription-only services. Install these packages on each host machine that will run a Eucalyptus service.

substep.cmd: Install the license files to access the enterprise repository.

step.cmd: Configure the Euca2ools package repository on each host machine that will run a Eucalyptus service or Euca2ools:

info.p: Enter y when prompted to install this package.

step.cmd: Configure the EPEL package repository on each host machine that will run a Eucalyptus service or Euca2ools:

info.p: Enter y when prompted to install this package.

step.cmd: If you are installing on RHEL 6, you must enable the Optional repository in Red Hat Network for each NC, as follows:

substep.cmd: Go to http://rhn.redhat.com and navigate to the system that will run the NC.
Make sure the RHEL Server Optional checkbox is checked.

step.cmd: The following steps should be performed on each NC host machine.

substep.cmd: Install the Eucalyptus node controller software on each NC host:
Remove the default libvirt network. This step allows the eucanetd dhcpd server to start.

info.codeblock: virsh net-destroy default virsh net-autostart default --disable

substep.cmd: Check that the KVM device node has proper permissions.

info.p: Verify the output shows that the device node is owned by user root and group kvm.
If your kvm device node does not have proper permissions, you need to reboot your NC host.

step.cmd: On each CLC host machine, install the Eucalyptus cloud controller software.
Install the services image package on the machine hosting the primary CLC:
step.info: This installs worker images for both the Load Balancer and Imaging services.

step.cmd: On the UFS host machine, install the Eucalyptus cloud controller software.
(Optional) On the UFS host machine, also install the Management Console.
step.info: For more information, see the Console Guide.

step.cmd: Install the software for the remaining Eucalyptus services. The following example shows services being installed on the same host. We recommend that you use a different host machine for each service, when possible:
step.info: This installs the cloud controller (CC), storage controller (SC), and Walrus backend (WS) services.

step.cmd: (Optional) If you are a subscriber and use SAN, run the appropriate command for your device on each CLC host machine:
(Optional) If you are a subscriber and use SAN, run the appropriate command for your device on each SC host machine:
After you have installed Eucalyptus, test multicast connectivity between each CLC and Walrus, and SC.

substep.cmd: Install the network tomography package on the Cloud Controller, Cluster Controller, Storage Controller, and any host machines running a Walrus backend service.

Run the network-tomography tool on the Cloud Controller, Cluster Controller, Storage Controller, and any host machines running a Walrus backend service, passing a list of IP addresses for each of these host machines.
substep.info: /usr/bin/network-tomography 192.168.51.174 192.168.51.196 192.168.51.86 192.168.51.99 This tool may take up to an hour to run. Check the output for reports of packet loss. If there is significant packet loss, ensure that your network is available and multicast enabled.

taskbody.postreq: You are now ready to Configure Eucalyptus.
